articles.headline: Coronavirus Brings a Surge to News Sites
articles.snippet: Many journalists are covering a once-in-a-lifetime story from home, thanks to Zoom and Slack. But as readers flock to large news outlets, ads are starting to disappear.
articles.abstract: Many journalists are covering a once-in-a-lifetime story from home, thanks to Zoom and Slack. But as readers flock to large news outlets, ads are starting to disappear.
articles.lead_paragraph: They Slack. And the journalists stuck working from home also plan their coverage through videoconferencing applications like Google Hangouts, Zoom, UberConference, BlueJeans and Nexi.
articles.byline: By Marc Tracy

articles.headline: When Stocking Grocery Shelves Turns Dangerous
articles.snippet: Grocery stores have been deemed essential businesses, meaning their employees are worried about being exposed to the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: Grocery stores have been deemed essential businesses, meaning their employees are worried about being exposed to the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: They are a new class of emergency medical workers: the more than two million Americans reporting to work each day to sell food and other household staples to a country in the midst of a coronavirus pandemic.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery, David Yaffe-Bellany and Rachel Wharton

articles.headline: Stock Market’s Gain Under Trump Vanishes
articles.snippet: With another fall on Friday, the Dow Jones average is now lower than it was when President Trump took office.
articles.abstract: With another fall on Friday, the Dow Jones average is now lower than it was when President Trump took office.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before he was sworn in as president, Donald J. Trump made clear that he would treat the stock market as a crucial yardstick of his success in office.
articles.byline: By David Enrich and Matt Phillips

articles.headline: One in Five Americans Ordered to Stay Home in Coronavirus Crackdown
articles.snippet: Strict new directives in New York, California, Illinois and other states were intended to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: Strict new directives in New York, California, Illinois and other states were intended to slow the spread of the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — America plunged into a deeper state of disruption and paralysis on Friday as New York and Illinois announced a broad series of measures aimed at keeping tens of millions of residents cloistered in their homes, following similar actions by California and a patchwork of restrictions from coast to coast.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Jesse McKinley

articles.headline: As Crisis Deepens, Companies Hand Out Cash to Workers
articles.snippet: Some large businesses are paying employees while they stay home. Others are offering bonuses to those who must keep going in.
articles.abstract: Some large businesses are paying employees while they stay home. Others are offering bonuses to those who must keep going in.
articles.lead_paragraph: A thousand dollars here, $200 there, free lunch once a week, stipends for electronic equipment: Those are some of the ways the biggest companies in the United States have come up with to help their employees get through the coronavirus crisis.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter

articles.headline: Coronavirus Recession Looms, Its Course ‘Unrecognizable’
articles.snippet: The U.S. economic outlook darkens daily, with millions facing unemployment and businesses in a steep decline.
articles.abstract: The U.S. economic outlook darkens daily, with millions facing unemployment and businesses in a steep decline.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy is facing a plunge into uncharted waters.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: How It All Came Apart for Bernie Sanders
articles.snippet: The Sanders campaign appeared on the brink of a commanding lead in the Democratic race. But a series of fateful decisions and internal divisions have left him all but vanquished.
articles.abstract: The Sanders campaign appeared on the brink of a commanding lead in the Democratic race. But a series of fateful decisions and internal divisions have left him all but vanquished.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read more: Bernie Sanders has officially ended his 2020 presidential campaign.]
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: The Coronavirus’s Rampage Through a Suburban Nursing Home
articles.snippet: Two-thirds of Life Care Center’s residents and 47 of its workers fell ill. Thirty-five people died. We investigated what went wrong.
articles.abstract: Two-thirds of Life Care Center’s residents and 47 of its workers fell ill. Thirty-five people died. We investigated what went wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIRKLAND, Wash. — Loretta Rapp, 79, was easy to spot as she zipped through the Life Care Center nursing home in her electric wheelchair, dressed in one of her bright muumuus.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Serge F. Kovaleski

articles.headline: ‘Terrified’ Package Delivery Employees Are Going to Work Sick
articles.snippet: Truckers and warehouse workers at UPS and FedEx feel they have no choice but to keep showing up, even with coronavirus-like symptoms.
articles.abstract: Truckers and warehouse workers at UPS and FedEx feel they have no choice but to keep showing up, even with coronavirus-like symptoms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hour after hour, day after day, the packages keep arriving: food, medicine, clothes, toys and a million other items brought to the doorsteps and building lobbies of Americans who are hunkering down as the coronavirus sweeps the land.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Used to Meeting Challenges With Bluster and Force, Trump Confronts a Crisis Unlike Any Before
articles.snippet: The ways he dealt with crises in his business, real estate and even his personal life prove jarring as he leads the government’s response to a pandemic.
articles.abstract: The ways he dealt with crises in his business, real estate and even his personal life prove jarring as he leads the government’s response to a pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During his campaign for the White House in 2016, President Trump’s advisers briefly tried to run through with him how he would address a large-scale disaster if he won. What, for instance, would he have done during Hurricane Katrina?
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Italy, Pandemic’s New Epicenter, Has Lessons for the World
articles.snippet: The country’s experience shows that steps to isolate the coronavirus and limit people’s movement need to be put in place early, with absolute clarity, then strictly enforced.
articles.abstract: The country’s experience shows that steps to isolate the coronavirus and limit people’s movement need to be put in place early, with absolute clarity, then strictly enforced.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — As Italy’s coronavirus infections ticked above 400 cases and deaths hit the double digits, the leader of the governing Democratic Party posted a picture of himself clinking glasses for “an aperitivo in Milan,” urging people “not to change our habits.”
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz, Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo

articles.headline: Governments and Companies Race to Make Masks Vital to Virus Fight
articles.snippet: President Trump resists using emergency powers to compel production, saying companies will voluntarily provide much-needed protective gear.
articles.abstract: President Trump resists using emergency powers to compel production, saying companies will voluntarily provide much-needed protective gear.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump on Saturday sought to assure an anxious American public that help was on the way to overwhelmed hospitals, and that private companies had agreed to provide desperately needed medical supplies to fight the fast-spreading coronavirus.
articles.byline: By Rachel Abrams, Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Andrew Jacobs, Vanessa Friedman and Michael Rothfeld

articles.headline: A Boom Time for the Bean Industry
articles.snippet: “It’s just shocking,” one bean supplier said. “I used to be the loneliest man at the farmer’s market.”
articles.abstract: “It’s just shocking,” one bean supplier said. “I used to be the loneliest man at the farmer’s market.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim McGreevy has worked in the bean business for more than 30 years. But when he scanned the bean aisles at a grocery store in Pullman, Wash., on Sunday, he saw something he had never seen before: empty shelves.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Help Wanted: Grocery Stores, Pizza Chains and Amazon Are Hiring
articles.snippet: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
articles.abstract: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: The volume of food and paper products passing through a warehouse just outside Los Angeles is up 30 percent from the same time a year ago. Pizza deliveries are surging as people around the country hunker down.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Emergency Economic Rescue Plan in Limbo as Democrats Block Action
articles.snippet: Democrats voted against moving forward on a plan expected to cost $1.8 trillion or more, seeking stronger protections for workers and stricter rules for bailed-out businesses.
articles.abstract: Democrats voted against moving forward on a plan expected to cost $1.8 trillion or more, seeking stronger protections for workers and stricter rules for bailed-out businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats on Sunday blocked action on an emerging deal to prop up an economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, paralyzing the progress of a nearly $2 trillion government rescue package they said failed to adequately protect workers or impose strict enough restrictions on bailed-out businesses.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane, Jim Tankersley and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: In a Pandemic, Religion Can Be a Balm and a Risk
articles.snippet: As scientists and politicians struggle for a response to the coronavirus, many people are turning to faith. But some practices raise public health concerns.
articles.abstract: As scientists and politicians struggle for a response to the coronavirus, many people are turning to faith. But some practices raise public health concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Down on earth, the coronavirus outbreak was felling lives, livelihoods and normalcy. A nation-spanning blessing seemed called for. So up went a priest in a small airplane, rumbling overhead at an epidemiologically safe distance from the troubles below, wielding a sacred golden vessel from a cockpit-turned-pulpit.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee

articles.headline: She Was More Than a Statistic in a Pandemic: ‘We Didn’t Want Her to Get Lost’
articles.snippet: Loretta Mendoza Dionisio, outgoing and unstoppable, died of the coronavirus, a statistic in a growing U.S. count. But her life meant much more.
articles.abstract: Loretta Mendoza Dionisio, outgoing and unstoppable, died of the coronavirus, a statistic in a growing U.S. count. But her life meant much more.
articles.lead_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry

articles.headline: ‘Wartime President’? Trump Rewrites History in an Election Year
articles.snippet: The president is brazenly grabbing his only clear option to bolster his re-election hopes, portraying himself as a take-charge leader the country can’t afford to lose.
articles.abstract: The president is brazenly grabbing his only clear option to bolster his re-election hopes, portraying himself as a take-charge leader the country can’t afford to lose.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the economy faltering and the political landscape unsettled as the coronavirus death toll climbs, a stark and unavoidable question now confronts President Trump and his advisers: Can he save his campaign for re-election when so much is suddenly going so wrong?
articles.byline: By Annie Karni, Maggie Haberman and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Rupert Murdoch Put His Son in Charge of Fox. It Was a Dangerous Mistake.
articles.snippet: The 48-year-old Lachlan Murdoch stood by as Fox News hosts played down the danger of the deadly coronavirus to their viewers.
articles.abstract: The 48-year-old Lachlan Murdoch stood by as Fox News hosts played down the danger of the deadly coronavirus to their viewers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Fox News, Suzanne Scott, reacted swiftly to the threat of the coronavirus in late February: She ordered the bright, open new offices disinfected, installed hand sanitizer stations around the office and boldly canceled the company’s major ad sales event.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: The U.S. Needs China’s Masks, as Acrimony Grows
articles.snippet: Beijing has signaled a willingness to supply the U.S. as its outbreak spreads. Increasingly harsh language and logistical issues could make it difficult to reach deals.
articles.abstract: Beijing has signaled a willingness to supply the U.S. as its outbreak spreads. Increasingly harsh language and logistical issues could make it difficult to reach deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — American front-line medical personnel are running desperately short of masks and protective equipment as they battle the coronavirus outbreak. China, already the world’s largest producer of such gear by far, has ramped up factory output and is now signaling that it wants to help.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Spit On, Yelled At, Attacked: Chinese-Americans Fear for Their Safety
articles.snippet: As bigots blame them for the coronavirus and President Trump labels it the “Chinese virus,” many Chinese-Americans say they are terrified of what could come next.
articles.abstract: As bigots blame them for the coronavirus and President Trump labels it the “Chinese virus,” many Chinese-Americans say they are terrified of what could come next.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Yuanyuan Zhu was walking to her gym in San Francisco on March 9, thinking the workout could be her last for a while, when she noticed that a man was shouting at her. He was yelling an expletive about China. Then a bus passed, she recalled, and he screamed after it, “Run them over.”
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: As Coronavirus Surveillance Escalates, Personal Privacy Plummets
articles.snippet: Tracking entire populations to combat the pandemic now could open the doors to more invasive forms of government snooping later.
articles.abstract: Tracking entire populations to combat the pandemic now could open the doors to more invasive forms of government snooping later.
articles.lead_paragraph: In South Korea, government agencies are harnessing surveillance-camera footage, smartphone location data and credit card purchase records to help trace the recent movements of coronavirus patients and establish virus transmission chains.
articles.byline: By Natasha Singer and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Small Businesses Seek a Crisis Lifeline Beyond Loans
articles.snippet: Many owners fear taking on debt they are not sure they can repay and are looking to the federal government for more than low-interest disaster loans.
articles.abstract: Many owners fear taking on debt they are not sure they can repay and are looking to the federal government for more than low-interest disaster loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read our Coronavirus Relief Small Business F.A.Q.]
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: The Fed Goes All In With Unlimited Bond-Buying Plan
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve will buy bonds as needed to calm markets, and will buy corporate debt in a series of emergency lending programs.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve will buy bonds as needed to calm markets, and will buy corporate debt in a series of emergency lending programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve, determined to try to keep the spread of the coronavirus from devastating the American economy, rolled out a series of sweeping new programs on Monday meant to shore up large and small businesses and keep markets functioning.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Big Tech Could Emerge From Coronavirus Crisis Stronger Than Ever
articles.snippet: Amazon is hiring aggressively to meet customer demand. Traffic has soared on Facebook and YouTube. And cloud computing has become essential to home workers.
articles.abstract: Amazon is hiring aggressively to meet customer demand. Traffic has soared on Facebook and YouTube. And cloud computing has become essential to home workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — While the rest of the economy is tanking from the crippling impact of the coronavirus, business at the biggest technology companies is holding steady — even thriving.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Jack Nicas, Steve Lohr and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Joe Biden Is Trying to Be Heard on the Virus. Can He Break Through?
articles.snippet: As President Trump holds daily briefings, Mr. Biden has kept a low profile, worrying Democrats who feel the president needs to be challenged more robustly.
articles.abstract: As President Trump holds daily briefings, Mr. Biden has kept a low profile, worrying Democrats who feel the president needs to be challenged more robustly.
articles.lead_paragraph: With President Trump providing daily televised briefings and governors like Andrew M. Cuomo emerging as national leaders during the coronavirus pandemic, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is still grappling with how to position himself as a prominent voice on a crisis that is pushing traditional politics to the background.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Top Senate Democrat and Treasury Secretary Say They Are Near a Stimulus Deal
articles.snippet: Hours after Democrats blocked the nearly $2 trillion package, a marathon set of private negotiations appeared to have yielded important compromises.
articles.abstract: Hours after Democrats blocked the nearly $2 trillion package, a marathon set of private negotiations appeared to have yielded important compromises.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Treasury secretary and the top Senate Democrat said late Monday that they were on the brink of a deal on a nearly $2 trillion emergency economic aid measure to respond to the coronavirus pandemic, after a marathon day of talks as Democrats demanded stronger protections for workers and restrictions for bailed-out businesses.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Nicholas Fandos
